oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Mt. Ararat Cemetery Sign
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gardner, Leigh Ann, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Finding Community
Cemeteries
African American cemeteries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Iron scrollwork arch mounted on square stacked limestone pillars. "Mt. Ararat Cemetery" is spelled out in wrought iron lettering, with running scroll of decorative motifs below and surrounding the simple iron cross atop the arch.

Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Nashville was established in 1869 by two African American benevolent groups, the Sons of Relief No. 1 and the Colored Benevolent Society. Hundreds, if not thousands, of African Americans have been buried here since that time.
